summary: MCU Films Ranked by Rotten Tomatoes Score
title: MCU Films Ranked by Rotten Tomatoes Score
body:
1. Black Panther (duh)
  2. Iron Man
  3. Thor: Ragnarok
  4. Spider-man: Homecoming
  5. The Avengers
  6. Captain America: Civil War
  7. Guardians of the Galaxy
  8. Captain America: the Winter Soldier (too low!)
  9. Doctor Strange (what?)
  10. Ant-Man and the Wasp (I liked this fine but it’s not top ten for me)
  11. Avengers: Infinity War
  12. Captain Marvel*
  13. Guardians of the Galaxy Vol 2.
  14. Ant-Man
  15. Iron Man 3
  16. Captain America: the First Avenger (too low!)
  17. Thor (from the amount of Loki fangirls on this site I think this is too low too)
  18. Avengers: Age of Ultron
  19. Iron Man 2
  20. Thor: The Dark World
  21. The Incredible Hulk

My comments in parentheses.

Listen, I am fine with a Guardians 2-level movie. But the critics have been wrong about some of these and gave low scores to films I love, so don’t anyone get disheartened by it being called “mediocre” in some headlines.

Plus it may go up or down based on new reviews.

summary: I saw captain marvel today it was awesome. Goose was a wonder, the friendship between Maria and Carol was so touching, Monica...
body: I saw captain marvel today it was awesome. Goose was a wonder, the friendship between Maria and Carol was so touching, Monica designing Carol new suit was incredible. Nick fury was so funny. The skrulls were not who we thought. This movie is really great. I think I will go see it again.

reblog.comment: I saw captain marvel today it was awesome. Goose was a wonder, the friendship between Maria and Carol was so touching, Monica designing Carol new suit was incredible. Nick fury was so funny. The skrulls were not who we thought. This movie is really great. I think I will go see it again.

Nick fury was so funny. The skrulls were not who we thought. This movie is really great. I think I will go see it again.

Nick fury was so funny. The skrulls were not who we thought. This movie is really great. I think I will go see it again.

I'm a SWEDISH man and 21 years old. I am an aspiring writer and loves Star Wars, Marvel, DC Comics and The Legend of Korra and plenty of other of things.

Also me: Human mess with Aspergers syndrome and ADD as well.

...Hi everyone

Oh, also. Another thing that you should know is that the phrase and name that is my username is part of a story that i will eventually write and does have a story within it, so please feel free to ask about, I will happily answer when I get time.

(Long bio, I know. But I keep forgetting to make a better one. Sorry)

summary:
you GUYS
I JUST SAW CAPTAIN MARVEL
CAPTAIN MARVEL
-
so im not going to say anything that could ruin your experience cause i am a...
body:
you GUYS

I JUST SAW CAPTAIN MARVEL

CAPTAIN MARVEL

-

so im not going to say anything that could ruin your experience cause i am a nice person after all

but i want to say SHE IS SO MF POWERFUL the movie shows she doesn’t need anyone to be great and i really appreciated that cause that’s an example we women all need to follow.

and the post credit scene? again THIS IS NOT A SPOILER it’s just so breathtaking i wanted to share w u

btw after i’ve seen it i walked out the cinema like IT ALL MAKES SENSE NOW

you’ll literally understand everything you’ve seen in the mcu good luck to you americans

peace and enjoy the movie✌🏻

title: My thoughts on Captain Marvel
body:
(SPOILERS AHOY! GIGANTIC SPOILERS AHOY!)

I went to see it today. Here are my thoughts:

  • It was fun to see that they used the “that’s no cat, it’s a flerken” thing from the comic books. That’s the sort of thing that’s a treat for us fans to recognize.
  • All the songs on the soundtrack ranged from good to great.Having the Stan Lee cameo be a b o u t the Stan Lee cameo in Mallrats was a nice way to get a meta-cameo. (Or “cameoception,” as people would have put it back in 2014.)
  • “Just A Girl” by No Doubt was a great song choice for the battle where Carol beats up her old crew. It sets the tone for the scene perfectly. (No pun intended.)
  • The idea of making the Skrulls innocent people who are just trying to survive was a surprise to everybody in the audience, I’d imagine.But it was an extra major surprise to me, since as a comic book fan I’ve known them as evil enemies of Earth since I set eyes on the Fantastic Four adventure where they first appeared.
  • While the movie does take place in the 90′s, we’re not being hit in the head with that fact. Yeah, there’s Carol crashing in a Blockbuster and using a phone booth, but there’s no dialogue that’s meant to sound funny to us 2019 people. Nothing like “George Bush’s son also becoming president? That’s even more unlikely than, I dunno, a gritty and realistic reboot of the Batman movies!” 
  • Going to a clip show of Carol’s memories so soon after the movie started was a mistake, in my opinion. The setting and environment of the movie are still so new at that point. The movie’s hinting at a different past for Carol when we don’t have a clear grasp of what she thinks her past is at that point.
  • It’s weird that Monica Rambeau, who’s about Carol’s age in the comics, is a child in this version. A funny, scene-stealing child, but still. Anyway, it was good to see another comics character who’s used the “Captain Marvel” name appear.
  • I was tremendously pleased with the way Carol responded when Yon-Rogg tried to make her fight him using no superpowers. She just blasted him without even waiting for him to finish talking, and stated that she had nothing to prove to him. That’s the way to do it–just blast the bad guy and get on with business. You don’t owe him the right to decide the conditions of the fight.
  • For several minutes after the movie-skrulls were revealed to be innocent, I kept thinking “They’ll turn out to be bad after all any second now, right? Right?” It took a while for me to realize that this was not going to happen.
  • It was cool how any non-Skrull could turn out to be a Skrull, but it was distracting, too. I never felt sure what was really going on. It’s hard to cheer for the heroes in a fight when you don’t know if they actually are the heroes. (Maybe that’s why they clarified that Skrulls can’t shoot energy like Carol does; that way we would feel secure in cheering for her.)
  • The Mar-Vell of this movie is an old woman. This is fine with me, since Mar-Vell’s only role is to be an older friend and colleague of Carol Danvers, and that would have been different from the comic book Mar-Vell anyway.

(SPOILERS AHOY! GIGANTIC SPOILERS AHOY!)

I went to see it today. Here are my thoughts:

  • It was fun to see that they used the “that’s no cat, it’s a flerken” thing from the comic books. That’s the sort of thing that’s a treat for us fans to recognize.
  • All the songs on the soundtrack ranged from good to great.Having the Stan Lee cameo be a b o u t the Stan Lee cameo in Mallrats was a nice way to get a meta-cameo. (Or “cameoception,” as people would have put it back in 2014.)
  • “Just A Girl” by No Doubt was a great song choice for the battle where Carol beats up her old crew. It sets the tone for the scene perfectly. (No pun intended.)
  • The idea of making the Skrulls innocent people who are just trying to survive was a surprise to everybody in the audience, I’d imagine.But it was an extra major surprise to me, since as a comic book fan I’ve known them as evil enemies of Earth since I set eyes on the Fantastic Four adventure where they first appeared.
  • While the movie does take place in the 90′s, we’re not being hit in the head with that fact. Yeah, there’s Carol crashing in a Blockbuster and using a phone booth, but there’s no dialogue that’s meant to sound funny to us 2019 people. Nothing like “George Bush’s son also becoming president? That’s even more unlikely than, I dunno, a gritty and realistic reboot of the Batman movies!” 
  • Going to a clip show of Carol’s memories so soon after the movie started was a mistake, in my opinion. The setting and environment of the movie are still so new at that point. The movie’s hinting at a different past for Carol when we don’t have a clear grasp of what she thinks her past is at that point.
  • It’s weird that Monica Rambeau, who’s about Carol’s age in the comics, is a child in this version. A funny, scene-stealing child, but still. Anyway, it was good to see another comics character who’s used the “Captain Marvel” name appear.
  • I was tremendously pleased with the way Carol responded when Yon-Rogg tried to make her fight him using no superpowers. She just blasted him without even waiting for him to finish talking, and stated that she had nothing to prove to him. That’s the way to do it–just blast the bad guy and get on with business. You don’t owe him the right to decide the conditions of the fight.
  • For several minutes after the movie-skrulls were revealed to be innocent, I kept thinking “They’ll turn out to be bad after all any second now, right? Right?” It took a while for me to realize that this was not going to happen.
  • It was cool how any non-Skrull could turn out to be a Skrull, but it was distracting, too. I never felt sure what was really going on. It’s hard to cheer for the heroes in a fight when you don’t know if they actually are the heroes. (Maybe that’s why they clarified that Skrulls can’t shoot energy like Carol does; that way we would feel secure in cheering for her.)
  • The Mar-Vell of this movie is an old woman. This is fine with me, since Mar-Vell’s only role is to be an older friend and colleague of Carol Danvers, and that would have been different from the comic book Mar-Vell anyway.
